newsitem.title: INDIA: India markets sparkle in wake of credit easing.
newsitem.headline: India markets sparkle in wake of credit easing.

text.p: Indian markets reopened on Tuesday with some much-needed fizz injected by the central bank's announcement over the long weekend of a looser credit policy for the next six months.
"The phones are ringing again. People are asking positive questions. We're feeling good," Ramesh Damani, a member broker at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE), told Reuters.
Shares, gilts and the rupee all showed strength, but while the markets burst into life analysts said they were not issuing invites for a bulls' party.
The BSE top-30 index rose 98.75 points from Friday's close to close at a provisional 3,228.96, or 3.15 percent higher.

The rupee was quoted at 35.62 to the dollar late Tuesday, after closing on Friday at 35.67. But the strength was more evident in the forward market, where the six-month dollar premia fell to 1.30/1.32 rupees from 1.57/1.60 on Friday.
Gilts continued the uptrend begun in anticipation of the central bank's moves. The 13.50 percent 1997 issue yield was quoted at 12.18 percent on Tuesday, versus 12.72 on Friday.
The one-year T-bill yield was quoted at 12.00-12.25 percent on Tuesday versus 12.40-12.50 on Friday.
Analysts were not getting over-excited, however.
"I'm very cautious. It's a bit of a bear rally (on equities)," said one director of a foreign brokerage based here.
"It could go up to 3,300 in the current phase, thereafter it should react (downwards)," said Girish Desai, head of research at brokerage Prabhudas Lilladher.
"The market needs to find out whether the economic slowdown is temporary or rooted," Desai said.
October production figures for core industries, expected out sometime in mid-November, may provide some clues.

Analysts remained unconvinced by the Reserve Bank of India's decision to boost market liquidity by cutting banks' cash reserve requirement by a possible two percent to 10 percent in four stages over the next four months. However, they all described the measures as positive.
"Overall just because of the credit poilicy I don't see the fundamental situation changing, although it has improved the investment climate," Devesh Kumar, strategist at W.I. Carr said.
The market's expectations of corporate earnings, in the middle of the reporting season, remain weak.
"I don't think this rally will be sustained. We have to wait for the (half-year) results. These are not going to be very good," said Amish Choksi, a dealer at brokerage Amit Nalinkant.

The RBI's staggered approach to loosening credit means money supply remains fairly tight. The final two half-point cuts in January are contingent on monetary and price conditions at the time -- leaving some doubt whether they will happen.

In a note to clients R. Balakrishnan of Dil Vikas Finance Ltd wrote: "For the stock markets the credit policy provides a temporary salve. The economic fundamentals remain fluid and infrastructure bottlenecks remain."
He said he expected the BSE index to stay in a 2,900 to 3,400 zone for the next couple of months.
